values.description:
This PR trims down the `bitbucket-pipelines.yml` file by moving some functionality to script files.

It also adds a custom pipeline designed to generate benchmark data and upload that data to `https://api.ignitionrobotics.org`. You can see the rendered version of the benchmark data at [https://ignitionrobotics.org/dev](https://ignitionrobotics.org/dev). Note: one of the data points shown is incorrect ... I'll fix that soon.
values.title: Nightly benchmark

summary.raw:
This PR trims down the `bitbucket-pipelines.yml` file by moving some functionality to script files.

It also adds a custom pipeline designed to generate benchmark data and upload that data to `https://api.ignitionrobotics.org`. You can see the rendered version of the benchmark data at [https://ignitionrobotics.org/dev](https://ignitionrobotics.org/dev). Note: one of the data points shown is incorrect ... I'll fix that soon.
summary.html:
This PR trims down the bitbucket-pipelines.yml file by moving some functionality to script files.

It also adds a custom pipeline designed to generate benchmark data and upload that data to https://api.ignitionrobotics.org. You can see the rendered version of the benchmark data at https://ignitionrobotics.org/dev. Note: one of the data points shown is incorrect ... I'll fix that soon.

values.title: [Acropolis] Add ApplyJointForce system

summary.html:
In light of the discussions in pull request #246, I have added a system that can be used to apply forces to a joint. The way pending joint forces are accumulated may change in the future, but for now, I'm just doing += on the component.

I'm in favor of renaming JointController to something else so it doesn't cause confusion going forward.

cc @Silvio Traversaro , @Michael Grey , @Diego Ferigo

values.description:
Needs [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/102/change-serialized-field-from-string-to/diff) ign-msgs PR.

I considered creating a template of `Component` for components that will be serialized to Ignition Messages. I can do it in this PR if someone feels strongly about it, or we can try to tackle it before Blueprint.

---

This PR will be smaller once pull request #251 is merged forward.
values.title: [Blueprint] Serialization for more components

summary.raw:
Needs [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/102/change-serialized-field-from-string-to/diff) ign-msgs PR.

I considered creating a template of `Component` for components that will be serialized to Ignition Messages. I can do it in this PR if someone feels strongly about it, or we can try to tackle it before Blueprint.

---

This PR will be smaller once pull request #251 is merged forward.
summary.html:
Needs this ign-msgs PR.

I considered creating a template of Component for components that will be serialized to Ignition Messages. I can do it in this PR if someone feels strongly about it, or we can try to tackle it before Blueprint.

This PR will be smaller once pull request #251 is merged forward.

values.description:
This is a port of the [LiftDragPlugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/plugins/LiftDragPlugin.cc). Most of the code is copied verbatim from the previous plugin, but the changes I  made some at [LiftDragPlugin.cc:287-291](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/9163b9822ef402cb61e7ccbd52d32273af370b7f#Lsrc/systems/lift_drag/LiftDrag.ccT287) and [LiftDragPlugin.cc:424-441](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/9163b9822ef402cb61e7ccbd52d32273af370b7f#Lsrc/systems/lift_drag/LiftDrag.ccT424) would benefit from extra scrutiny.

In  429e2d0 I refactor the physics system so that the kinematic quantities of links are populated if a corresponding component is attached to the link.

## Dependencies:
* [ign-gazebo #254](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/254)
* [ign-physics #79](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/79/)


## Examples

**Simple Rotor Example**

Run:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -r  -f examples/worlds/lift_drag.sdf`

and on another terminal:

`ign topic -t "/model/lift_drag_demo_model/joint/rod_1_joint/cmd_force" -m ignition.msgs.Double  -p "data: 0.65"`

**Propeller Plane**

Run:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f examples/worlds/plane_propeller_demo.sdf -r`

and on another terminal:

`ign topic -t "/model/propeller_plane/joint/rod_1_joint/cmd_force" -m ignition.msgs.Double  -p "data: 70"`
values.title: [Acropolis] Port of LiftDragPlugin

summary.raw:
This is a port of the [LiftDragPlugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/plugins/LiftDragPlugin.cc). Most of the code is copied verbatim from the previous plugin, but the changes I  made some at [LiftDragPlugin.cc:287-291](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/9163b9822ef402cb61e7ccbd52d32273af370b7f#Lsrc/systems/lift_drag/LiftDrag.ccT287) and [LiftDragPlugin.cc:424-441](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/9163b9822ef402cb61e7ccbd52d32273af370b7f#Lsrc/systems/lift_drag/LiftDrag.ccT424) would benefit from extra scrutiny.

In  429e2d0 I refactor the physics system so that the kinematic quantities of links are populated if a corresponding component is attached to the link.

## Dependencies:
* [ign-gazebo #254](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/254)
* [ign-physics #79](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/79/)


## Examples

**Simple Rotor Example**

Run:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -r  -f examples/worlds/lift_drag.sdf`

and on another terminal:

`ign topic -t "/model/lift_drag_demo_model/joint/rod_1_joint/cmd_force" -m ignition.msgs.Double  -p "data: 0.65"`

**Propeller Plane**

Run:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f examples/worlds/plane_propeller_demo.sdf -r`

and on another terminal:

`ign topic -t "/model/propeller_plane/joint/rod_1_joint/cmd_force" -m ignition.msgs.Double  -p "data: 70"`
summary.html:
This is a port of the LiftDragPlugin. Most of the code is copied verbatim from the previous plugin, but the changes I made some at LiftDragPlugin.cc:287-291 and LiftDragPlugin.cc:424-441 would benefit from extra scrutiny.

In 429e2d0 I refactor the physics system so that the kinematic quantities of links are populated if a corresponding component is attached to the link.

Dependencies:

  • ign-gazebo #254
  • ign-physics #79

Examples

Simple Rotor Example

Run:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f examples/worlds/lift_drag.sdf

and on another terminal:

ign topic -t "/model/lift_drag_demo_model/joint/rod_1_joint/cmd_force" -m ignition.msgs.Double -p "data: 0.65"

Propeller Plane

Run:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -r -f examples/worlds/plane_propeller_demo.sdf -r

and on another terminal:

ign topic -t "/model/propeller_plane/joint/rod_1_joint/cmd_force" -m ignition.msgs.Double -p "data: 70"

values.description:
Store the recorded SDF as part of the `.tlog` file together with the rest of pose messages already stored using `ign-transport`.

Previously, SDF was stored as a separate `.sdf` file.

The SDF is published as a string `ign-transport` message just once, in the first iteration of simulation. The message topic is named by the base name of the recorded path `+ /sdf`, e.g. if the record path is `/tmp/log(1)`, then the file will be stored to `/tmp/log(1)/state.tlog` as before, and the SDF topic name is `/log(1)/sdf`. It cannot use the world name like other topics such as `/world/default/`, because we don’t know the world name before parsing the SDF.

## Testing

Record and playback:

```
cd ign-gazebo/examples/worlds
ign-gazebo -f log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf -v 4 -r
ign-gazebo -f log_playback.sdf -v 4 -r
```
values.title: [Blueprint] Log record SDF to ign-transport database file

summary.raw:

Previously, SDF was stored as a separate `.sdf` file.

The message topic is named by the base name of the recorded path `+ /sdf`, e.g. if the record path is `/tmp/log(1)`, then the file will be stored to `/tmp/log(1)/state.tlog` as before, and the SDF topic name is `/log(1)/sdf`. It cannot use the world name like other topics such as `/world/default/`, because we don’t know the world name before parsing the SDF.

## Testing

Record and playback:

```
cd ign-gazebo/examples/worlds
ign-gazebo -f log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf -v 4 -r
ign-gazebo -f log_playback.sdf -v 4 -r
```

summary.html:
Store the recorded SDF as part of the .tlog file together with the rest of pose messages already stored using ign-transport.

Previously, SDF was stored as a separate .sdf file.

The SDF is published as a string ign-transport message just once, in the first iteration of simulation. The message topic is named by the base name of the recorded path + /sdf, e.g. if the record path is /tmp/log(1), then the file will be stored to /tmp/log(1)/state.tlog as before, and the SDF topic name is /log(1)/sdf. It cannot use the world name like other topics such as /world/default/, because we don’t know the world name before parsing the SDF.

Testing

Record and playback:

cd ign-gazebo/examples/worlds
ign-gazebo -f log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf -v 4 -r
ign-gazebo -f log_playback.sdf -v 4 -r

values.description:
Still a work in progress, opening for visibility and early feedback.

Broken off the `distributed_transfer` branch.

Builds on top of:

* ~~Pull request #262~~ merged

## TODO

* ~~fix the tests~~
* ~~investigate why performance is much worse than current implementation~~ - performance is better at default [because](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/261/blueprint-wip-unify-network-and-sync/diff#comment-98528074) doesn't always step in sync.

---

# Motivation

There are several aspects of simulation which need to be kept in sync between primary and secondaries. 

1. Sim time
1. Performer state
1. Performer <-> secondary affinities

The current implementation synchronizes each of them separately, state is only going one-way when it should be going 2 ways, and affinities are only set at startup when they should be able to change during simulation. 

# Proposal

. | Current | Proposed
-- | -- | --
Sim time | Initiated from primary to secondaries through the `step` topic and secondaries report back the end of a step through the `stepAck` topic. | Keep topics, use new messages (also experimented with services, but topics seemed more appropriate because we will soon have the GUI as a non-blocking secondary)
. | Secondaries are also stepped by the `SimulationRunner` through the `Step` function. This means that the 2 different "step sources" must be kept in sync through a condition variable. | Secondaries are no longer stepped by `SimulationRunner`, they're only stepped via the topic
. | Not well defined what should happen if secondaries and primary are run for a different number of iterations. | Secondaries ignore things like total iteration number and update rate. They just do what the primary asks until `Stop` is received.
State |  Reported from secondaries to primary through the `state_update` topic, which must be kept in sync with the `step` topic | Send secondary state updates in the end of an iteration as part of `step_ack` and avoid one extra synchronization mechanism.
. |  Primary doesn't report state to secondaries. | Primary will send state when a new performer is assigned to a secondary (`distributed_transfer` branch)
Affinities | Affinities are assigned only at startup through `prefix/affinity` services  | Affinity changes are sent as part of `SimulationStep`.
. | Initial distribution through performer round-robin | Initial distribution through levels round-robin, so all performers in the same level end up in the same secondary. 
. | No subsequent distribution | Subsequent distribution done according to the levels where performers currently are (`distributed_transfer` branch)
values.title: [Blueprint] Unify network and sync managers

summary.raw:
Still a work in progress, opening for visibility and early feedback.

Broken off the `distributed_transfer` branch.

Builds on top of:

* ~~Pull request #262~~ merged

## TODO

* ~~fix the tests~~
* ~~investigate why performance is much worse than current implementation~~ - performance is better at default [because](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/261/blueprint-wip-unify-network-and-sync/diff#comment-98528074) doesn't always step in sync.

---

# Motivation

There are several aspects of simulation which need to be kept in sync between primary and secondaries. 

1. Sim time
1. Performer state
1. Performer <-> secondary affinities

The current implementation synchronizes each of them separately, state is only going one-way when it should be going 2 ways, and affinities are only set at startup when they should be able to change during simulation. 

# Proposal

. | Current | Proposed
-- | -- | --
Sim time | Initiated from primary to secondaries through the `step` topic and secondaries report back the end of a step through the `stepAck` topic. | Keep topics, use new messages (also experimented with services, but topics seemed more appropriate because we will soon have the GUI as a non-blocking secondary)
. | Secondaries are also stepped by the `SimulationRunner` through the `Step` function. This means that the 2 different "step sources" must be kept in sync through a condition variable. | Secondaries are no longer stepped by `SimulationRunner`, they're only stepped via the topic
. | Not well defined what should happen if secondaries and primary are run for a different number of iterations. | Secondaries ignore things like total iteration number and update rate. They just do what the primary asks until `Stop` is received.
State |  Reported from secondaries to primary through the `state_update` topic, which must be kept in sync with the `step` topic | Send secondary state updates in the end of an iteration as part of `step_ack` and avoid one extra synchronization mechanism.
. |  Primary doesn't report state to secondaries. | Primary will send state when a new performer is assigned to a secondary (`distributed_transfer` branch)
Affinities | Affinities are assigned only at startup through `prefix/affinity` services  | Affinity changes are sent as part of `SimulationStep`.
. | Initial distribution through performer round-robin | Initial distribution through levels round-robin, so all performers in the same level end up in the same secondary. 
. | No subsequent distribution | Subsequent distribution done according to the levels where performers currently are (`distributed_transfer` branch)
summary.html:
Still a work in progress, opening for visibility and early feedback.

Broken off the distributed_transfer branch.

Builds on top of:

  • Pull request #262 merged

TODO

  • fix the tests
  • investigate why performance is much worse than current implementation - performance is better at default because doesn't always step in sync.

Motivation

There are several aspects of simulation which need to be kept in sync between primary and secondaries.

  1. Sim time
  2. Performer state
  3. Performer <-> secondary affinities

The current implementation synchronizes each of them separately, state is only going one-way when it should be going 2 ways, and affinities are only set at startup when they should be able to change during simulation.

Proposal

. Current Proposed
Sim time Initiated from primary to secondaries through the step topic and secondaries report back the end of a step through the stepAck topic. Keep topics, use new messages (also experimented with services, but topics seemed more appropriate because we will soon have the GUI as a non-blocking secondary)
. Secondaries are also stepped by the SimulationRunner through the Step function. This means that the 2 different "step sources" must be kept in sync through a condition variable. Secondaries are no longer stepped by SimulationRunner, they're only stepped via the topic
. Not well defined what should happen if secondaries and primary are run for a different number of iterations. Secondaries ignore things like total iteration number and update rate. They just do what the primary asks until Stop is received.
State Reported from secondaries to primary through the state_update topic, which must be kept in sync with the step topic Send secondary state updates in the end of an iteration as part of step_ack and avoid one extra synchronization mechanism.
. Primary doesn't report state to secondaries. Primary will send state when a new performer is assigned to a secondary (distributed_transfer branch)
Affinities Affinities are assigned only at startup through prefix/affinity services Affinity changes are sent as part of SimulationStep.
. Initial distribution through performer round-robin Initial distribution through levels round-robin, so all performers in the same level end up in the same secondary.
. No subsequent distribution Subsequent distribution done according to the levels where performers currently are (distributed_transfer branch)

values.description:
I needed a mechanism to add performers during a simulation run (after load). Spawned models are likely to be performers.

Requires #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/107

## Testing

1. `ign gazebo levels_no_performers.sdf -v 4 --levels`
2. `ign service -s /world/levels/level/set_performer --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 2000 --req 'data: "vehicle_blue"'`
3. ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 4.0}"
values.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

values.description:
Only the model's pose was being reported from the secondaries to the primary during distributed simulation. This PR adds a `descendants` helper function and uses it in the `SyncManager` so that individual link poses are also transmitted.

I also added a link to the distributed example to exemplify the fix; keep an eye on the yellow cylinder:

Before | After
-- | --
![before.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3515920985-before.gif) | ![after.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3815838413-after.gif)
values.title: [Blueprint] Descendants

summary.raw:
Only the model's pose was being reported from the secondaries to the primary during distributed simulation. This PR adds a `descendants` helper function and uses it in the `SyncManager` so that individual link poses are also transmitted.

I also added a link to the distributed example to exemplify the fix; keep an eye on the yellow cylinder:

![before.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3515920985-before.gif) | ![after.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3815838413-after.gif)
summary.html:

values.description:
Depends on this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/517)

The scene params are needed by the rendering sensor system so we can set the camera’s scene properties to match those used by the gui render window.

To test, run:

```
ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/camera_sensor.sdf
```

You should notice that the background in the Image display widget is no longer black

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/524428422-Screenshot_from_2019-04-12_17-48-02.png)
‌

The colors between the gui and the camera sensor are still inconsistent but that’s a different problem.
values.title: [Blueprint] Load scene parameters from SDF

The colors between the gui and the camera sensor are still inconsistent but that’s a different problem.

Refactored `UniqueFilePath()` and `UniqueDirectoryPath()` to ign-common `Filesystems.cc`.

Depends on [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/187/filesystem-functions-to-create-unique/diff) in ign-common.

Pulled out of the `log_sdf_as_msg` branch PR because that one is targeting Blueprint now. These functions are also better covered in tests outside of the plugin’s private class.

values.description:
removed all `<emissive>` elements from materials in all worlds. The property is meant to be used for self-illuminating visuals. For other visuals, this property should be set to black or left unspecified \(which defaults to black\).

Here's a comparison of `shapes.sdf` world. The right image is the result of removing the `<emissive>` sdf element. The objects no longer appear overly bright / white.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1961698663-shapes_emissive_compare.png)
values.title: [Blueprint] Remove emissive component from visual materials

summary.raw:
removed all `<emissive>` elements from materials in all worlds. The property is meant to be used for self-illuminating visuals. For other visuals, this property should be set to black or left unspecified \(which defaults to black\).

Here's a comparison of `shapes.sdf` world. The right image is the result of removing the `<emissive>` sdf element. The objects no longer appear overly bright / white.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1961698663-shapes_emissive_compare.png)
summary.html:
removed all <emissive> elements from materials in all worlds. The property is meant to be used for self-illuminating visuals. For other visuals, this property should be set to black or left unspecified (which defaults to black).

Here's a comparison of shapes.sdf world. The right image is the result of removing the <emissive> sdf element. The objects no longer appear overly bright / white.

values.description:
This is a port of the [Wind Plugin from Gazebo classic](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/plugins/WindPlugin.cc?at=default). Notable changes are:

  * `forceApproximationScalingFactor` is initialized to 1.0 instead of 0.
  * `directionMean` is initialized with the first value of `direction`. This is to avoid the filter always ramping up from zero.
  * `Wind::WindPrivate::linearVel` in Gazebo classic is now represented by the `WorldLinearVelocitySeed` component on the Wind entity
  * The component `WorldLinearVelocity` on the Wind entity is analogous to the result of `Wind::WorldLinearVel()` in Gazebo classic

## Dependencies

* ign-gazebo PR #256
* ign-gazebo PR #269 (This is merged in this branch for expediency)

## Example:
```
ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/wind.sdf
```

To change the velocity seed:

```
ign topic -t "/world/wind_demo/wind/" -m ignition.msgs.Wind  -p "linear_velocity: {x:-50, y:50}, enable_wind: true"
```
values.title: [Acropolis] Port Wind plugin

summary.raw:
This is a port of the [Wind Plugin from Gazebo classic](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/plugins/WindPlugin.cc?at=default). Notable changes are:

  * `forceApproximationScalingFactor` is initialized to 1.0 instead of 0.
  * `directionMean` is initialized with the first value of `direction`. This is to avoid the filter always ramping up from zero.
  * `Wind::WindPrivate::linearVel` in Gazebo classic is now represented by the `WorldLinearVelocitySeed` component on the Wind entity
  * The component `WorldLinearVelocity` on the Wind entity is analogous to the result of `Wind::WorldLinearVel()` in Gazebo classic

## Dependencies

* ign-gazebo PR #256
* ign-gazebo PR #269 (This is merged in this branch for expediency)

## Example:
```
ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/wind.sdf
```

To change the velocity seed:

```
ign topic -t "/world/wind_demo/wind/" -m ignition.msgs.Wind  -p "linear_velocity: {x:-50, y:50}, enable_wind: true"
```
summary.html:
This is a port of the Wind Plugin from Gazebo classic. Notable changes are:

  • forceApproximationScalingFactor is initialized to 1.0 instead of 0.
  • directionMean is initialized with the first value of direction. This is to avoid the filter always ramping up from zero.
  • Wind::WindPrivate::linearVel in Gazebo classic is now represented by the WorldLinearVelocitySeed component on the Wind entity
  • The component WorldLinearVelocity on the Wind entity is analogous to the result of Wind::WorldLinearVel() in Gazebo classic

Dependencies

  • ign-gazebo PR #256
  • ign-gazebo PR #269 (This is merged in this branch for expediency)

Example:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/wind.sdf

To change the velocity seed:

ign topic -t "/world/wind_demo/wind/" -m ignition.msgs.Wind  -p "linear_velocity: {x:-50, y:50}, enable_wind: true"

values.description:
Redo of pull request #265, now using a cache.

---

I have some ideas on how to improve performance, such as:

* Throttling the broadcast of full performer state from secondaries to primary
* Be sure to send full state once the performer changes levels, because that may prompt a secondary change

I think these can go in subsequent PRs though.
values.title: [Blueprint] Descendants

summary.html:
Redo of pull request #265, now using a cache.

I have some ideas on how to improve performance, such as:

  • Throttling the broadcast of full performer state from secondaries to primary
  • Be sure to send full state once the performer changes levels, because that may prompt a secondary change

I think these can go in subsequent PRs though.

values.description:
Work in progress for the entity tree UI populated using the `EntityComponentManager`.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1432105045-tree_1.png)
**New dependency**: `sudo apt install qml-module-qtqml-models2`

## Summary

* Created new type of plugin, `ignition::gazebo::GuiSystem`, which can use the ECM like `ignition::gazebo::System`s do.
* Pure ign-gui plugins inheriting from `ignition::gui::Plugin` are still supported.
* Install GUI plugins in a different path because ign-gui crawls that path to populate the plugin menu

## TODO

In the future:

* Implement the rest of @{5b6a0f313df2033d0d9a151a} 's design \(instead of the default Windows XPish look\)
* Send updates the other way around \(GUI -> Server\)

values.description:

This is meant to be used by pull request #285 to only send updates to the GUI when needed.

values.description: I'm seeing a race condition when launching ign-gazebo with `camera_sensor.sdf` world. The Scene3D gui plugin often receives an empty scene msg from the SceneBroadcaster system because the scene graph has not been populated yet. This PR delays the advertising the scene service and topics until after the first update when entities are added to the scene graph.
values.title: [Blueprint] Delay scene broadcaster transport setup

summary.raw: I'm seeing a race condition when launching ign-gazebo with `camera_sensor.sdf` world. The Scene3D gui plugin often receives an empty scene msg from the SceneBroadcaster system because the scene graph has not been populated yet. This PR delays the advertising the scene service and topics until after the first update when entities are added to the scene graph.
summary.html: I'm seeing a race condition when launching ign-gazebo with camera_sensor.sdf world. The Scene3D gui plugin often receives an empty scene msg from the SceneBroadcaster system because the scene graph has not been populated yet. This PR delays the advertising the scene service and topics until after the first update when entities are added to the scene graph.

values.description:
@azeey brought up the good point that inheriting from the component class is not ideal because we should be also reimplementing all the constructors. So I changed all the custom serialization we have so far to use custom stream operators instead, which are also more compact and less intrusive.

I also made 2 changes to `NoData` "tag" components:

* Removed the custom operators since they're not necessary for the component.** We should only need `De/Serialize` functions.
* They serialize to a `-` character instead of an empty string, so when receiving serialized messages we can tell a tag apart from a non-serialized component.



** Not to be confused with the operators added for the data wrapped inside the components.
values.title: [Blueprint] Operators instead of De/Serialize

summary.raw:
@azeey brought up the good point that inheriting from the component class is not ideal because we should be also reimplementing all the constructors. So I changed all the custom serialization we have so far to use custom stream operators instead, which are also more compact and less intrusive.

I also made 2 changes to `NoData` "tag" components:

* Removed the custom operators since they're not necessary for the component.** We should only need `De/Serialize` functions.
* They serialize to a `-` character instead of an empty string, so when receiving serialized messages we can tell a tag apart from a non-serialized component.



** Not to be confused with the operators added for the data wrapped inside the components.
summary.html:
@azeey brought up the good point that inheriting from the component class is not ideal because we should be also reimplementing all the constructors. So I changed all the custom serialization we have so far to use custom stream operators instead, which are also more compact and less intrusive.

I also made 2 changes to NoData "tag" components:

  • Removed the custom operators since they're not necessary for the component.** We should only need De/Serialize functions.
  • They serialize to a - character instead of an empty string, so when receiving serialized messages we can tell a tag apart from a non-serialized component.

** Not to be confused with the operators added for the data wrapped inside the components.

values.description:
This is the beginning of the feature that allows transplanting the state of a performer from one secondary to another.

## Try it out

Run the `distributed_levels` demo:

https://youtu.be/3plWn3Riizw

* The top terminal has the primary
* The middle terminal has the secondary which is simulating the green sphere (performer 2)
* The bottom terminal has the secondary which is simulating the yellow box (performer 3)
* Once the green sphere enters level 10, the primary detects that both entities are in the same level, so it needs to transplant one of them
* Since moving either entity would require transplanting the same number of entities (1), the exact choice is undefined - the yellow box gets picked.
* The box is transplanted from the bottom to the middle, and the bottom is left idle
* By the time the shapes reach the bottom of the slope, they're in separate levels again. **TODO** transplant one of them to the idle secondary.

## TODO

Before merging:

* Tests! The current logic is a bit clunky so I imagine there are many corner cases not covered yet.

Future:

* Redistribute performers to idle secondaries.
* Primary shouldn't need to wait for idle secondaries when stepping
* Keep velocity and acceleration in components, and set them as the entity is spawned into a new secondary. Currently it's visible that the yellow box slows down when it is transplanted.
values.title: [Blueprint] [WIP] Entity transplant in distributed sim

summary.raw:
This is the beginning of the feature that allows transplanting the state of a performer from one secondary to another.

## Try it out

Run the `distributed_levels` demo:

https://youtu.be/3plWn3Riizw

* The top terminal has the primary
* The middle terminal has the secondary which is simulating the green sphere (performer 2)
* The bottom terminal has the secondary which is simulating the yellow box (performer 3)
* Once the green sphere enters level 10, the primary detects that both entities are in the same level, so it needs to transplant one of them
* Since moving either entity would require transplanting the same number of entities (1), the exact choice is undefined - the yellow box gets picked.
* The box is transplanted from the bottom to the middle, and the bottom is left idle
* By the time the shapes reach the bottom of the slope, they're in separate levels again. **TODO** transplant one of them to the idle secondary.

## TODO

Before merging:

* Tests! The current logic is a bit clunky so I imagine there are many corner cases not covered yet.

Future:

* Redistribute performers to idle secondaries.
* Primary shouldn't need to wait for idle secondaries when stepping
* Keep velocity and acceleration in components, and set them as the entity is spawned into a new secondary. Currently it's visible that the yellow box slows down when it is transplanted.
summary.html:
This is the beginning of the feature that allows transplanting the state of a performer from one secondary to another.

Try it out

Run the distributed_levels demo:

https://youtu.be/3plWn3Riizw

  • The top terminal has the primary
  • The middle terminal has the secondary which is simulating the green sphere (performer 2)
  • The bottom terminal has the secondary which is simulating the yellow box (performer 3)
  • Once the green sphere enters level 10, the primary detects that both entities are in the same level, so it needs to transplant one of them
  • Since moving either entity would require transplanting the same number of entities (1), the exact choice is undefined - the yellow box gets picked.
  • The box is transplanted from the bottom to the middle, and the bottom is left idle
  • By the time the shapes reach the bottom of the slope, they're in separate levels again. TODO transplant one of them to the idle secondary.

TODO

Before merging:

  • Tests! The current logic is a bit clunky so I imagine there are many corner cases not covered yet.

Future:

  • Redistribute performers to idle secondaries.
  • Primary shouldn't need to wait for idle secondaries when stepping
  • Keep velocity and acceleration in components, and set them as the entity is spawned into a new secondary. Currently it's visible that the yellow box slows down when it is transplanted.
